titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Frank Lyon Polk Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Susan Grigg and John Espy

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 10:01

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of correpondence, letterbooks, documents, diaries, subject files and other materials documenting the personal life and professional career of Frank Lyon Polk. The bulk of the material relates to Polk's Department of State service and includes correspondence with political figures, letterpress copybooks (1915-1917), and diaries (1915-1920). Materials relating to the American Commission to Negotiate Peace and the League of Nations are also included.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Permission of the head of Manuscripts and Archives is necessary to examine boxes 64-67.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frank Lyon Polk Papers (MS 656). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Elizabeth Polk and her children, 1943.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Diary is available on microfilm (3 reels, 35mm.) from Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library, at cost. Order no. HM47.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in five series: I. Correspondence, 1898-1942. II. Diaries, 1915-1920. III. Subject Files, 1912-1921. IV. Chronological Files, 1915-1919. V. Politics and Memorabilia, 1883-1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Frank L. Polk Papers consist of twenty-two linear feet of correspondence, diaries, memoranda, telephone logs, memorabilia, and miscellaneous printed and mimeographed-material. They are arranged in five series:

Most of the papers in Series I and all the papers in Series II-IV are related to Polk's service as Counselor and Under Secretary in the State Department. Series V spans most of his life but relates mainly to his diplomatic service and to his political and civic activities in New York. There are only a few items related to his practice of law.

The Polk Papers were reprocessed in 1978 because the original arrangement and description by Charles Seymour and his staff had proved unsatisfactory to many researchers. The principal change was to separate most of the correspondence from the miscellaneous papers that are now arranged by subject (roughly as Seymour left them) in Series III. "Partial Index to Series I" is a listing by subject of correspondents whose letters have been removed from Seymour's subject arrangement.

Series I, Correspondence, is related mainly to Polk's service in the State Department. The major correspondents include Gordon Auchincloss, Ray Stannard Baker, Henry Bruère, Frederic R. Coudert, Sir Richard Crawford, John W. Davis, Henry P. Fletcher, David R. Francis, Norman Hapgood, Edward M. House, Jean Jusserand, Robert Lansing, Irwin B. Laughlin, Clarence H. Mackay, Walter Hines Page, William Phillips, Sir Cecil Arthur Spring Rice, Frederic N. Watriss, and Woodrow Wilson. Most of the letters are arranged alphabetically by correspondent, but there are also letterbooks containing copies of outgoing letters in chronological order from 1915 to 1917.

Notwithstanding the modification of Charles Seymour's arrangement of the papers, there are still some letters filed by subject in Series III. The series description for Series I and the introduction to the "Partial Index to Series I" explain how to find correspondence by writer and by subject.

There is also a small amount of correspondence in Series V, consisting mainly of personal letters, congratulations on Polk's various appointments, and exchanges with historians about events in World War I diplomacy.

Series II, Diaries, spans from 1915 to 1920. It consists partly of memoranda of conversations with representatives of foreign governments. Copies of individual memoranda were circulated within the State Department, and some of these copies are mixed with other papers in Series III.

Series III, Subject Files, consists of memoranda, correspondence, and miscellaneous papers spanning mainly from 1915 to 1920. Polk himself created very few of these items; the series consists rather of papers submitted to him and papers circulated among State Department staff. There are a great many carbon and mimeographed copies, some of which bear handwritten notations.

Series IV, Chronological Files, consists of transcripts of telephone conversations and several sequences of State Department mimeographed materials. The transcripts resulted from government wiretapping between 1915 and 1917.

Series V, Politics and Memorabilia, consists of certificates, clippings, photographs, routine correspondence, mementoes, and miscellaneous papers related to Polk's education, military and diplomatic service, and political and civic activities.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frank Lyon Polk was born in New York City on September 13, 1871. He graduated from Yale College (B.A., 1894) and Columbia University Law School (LL.D., 1897). Polk served on a variety of New York City boards and commissions (1906-1913) and as Corporation Counsel (1914-1915). He also served in the Department of State as Counselor (1915-1919), Acting Secretary of State (1918-1919), and Under Secretary of State (1919-1920). Polk headed the American Mission to Negotiate Peace (1919) and managed the 1924 Democratic presidential convention campaign of John W. Davis. Polk died in New York City on February 7, 1943. Here are some principal events in his public and personal life:

chronitem.event: born in New York City to William M. and Ida A. (Lyon) Polk
graduated from Groton School
graduated from Yale College
graduated from Columbia University Law School
served as clerk in the law firm of Evarts, Choate and Beaman
served as Captain and assistant on the Quartermaster Staff of General Ernst's Brigade
formed the legal partnership that became Alexander, Watriss and Polk
served on the New York City Board of Education
served on and presided over the Municipal Civil Service Commission of the City of New York
married Elizabeth Sturgis Potter
served as treasurer of the Bureau of Municipal Research
supported the candidacy of John Purroy Mitchel for Mayor of New York
served as Corporation Counsel of the City of New York
served as Counselor of the State Department
suffered from a nervous disorder
served as Acting Secretary of State
served as Under Secretary of State
headed the American Mission to Negotiate Peace in Paris
formed the legal partnership that became Davis Polk Wardwell Gardiner and Reed
managed John W. Davis's pre-convention and convention campaign for the Democratic nomination to the presidency
died in New York City

bioghist.p: For additional information about Polk's honors and appointments, see the Yale University Obituary Record of Graduates, 1942-1943. For brief assessments of Polk's career, see John W. Davis's memorial in the Association of the Bar of the City of New York Year Book, 1944, and Lawrence E. Gelfand's article in the Dictionary of American Biography,1941-1945.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: There are two sequences: loose letters, arranged alphabetically (boxes 1-14); and letterbooks, arranged chronologically (boxes 15-16).
"Partial Index to Series I" is a subject guide to correspondence in this series.
*An asterisk indicates folders of ten or more items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is in this order: manuscript books, 1916-1917; typed pages arranged alphabetically by country, 1915-1917; typed pages arranged chronologically, 1917-1920; appointment book, 1919.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Permission of the head of Manuscripts and Archives is necessary to examine these materials.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Permission of the head of Manuscripts and Archives is necessary to examine these materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sections are in alphabetical order. The arrangement of each section is chronological.

Many letters and memoranda in this series are not listed by writer. Some of the listed and some of the unlisted items can be located by writer from cross-references in the folder listing for Series I. The description of that series (p. 6) explains which items can be located in this way.

did.unittitle: Allied Naval Committee for the Adriatic: minutes of meeting (copy, in translation)

American Commission to Negotiate Peace, Chiefs of the Austro-Hungarian, Balkan, and Italian Divisions and the Intelligence Section of the Boundary Geography Division: memorandum to the Commissioners re: "Dalmatia and Fiume" (carbon)
"Memorandum of Rear Admiral A. P. Niblack, U.S. Navy, Regarding Fiume and Dalmatia,"
[Woodrow Wilson]: "Memorandum as to a Suggested Basis for Settlement of the Adriatic Question Submitted for Elaboration and Definition by Experts" (annotated copy)
Woodrow Wilson: memoranda and covering letters to Lansing (copies)

"Brief Notes on a Meeting [of Clemenceau, Lansing, Balfour, and Tittoni] which took place in M. Clemenceau's Office in the Ministry of War at 2:30 P.M. July 3, 1919" re: Italian interests in Asia Minor, the Adriatic, and the Klagenfurt Basin (carbon)
"Notes on Informal Conversation between Mr. Henry White and M. Tittoni on July 4, 1919" re: Italian interests in Asia Minor and the Adriatic (carbon)
U.S. Commissioners Plenipotentiary: draft cable to the Secretary of State re: conversation with Tittoni
Interallied Commission of Inquiry (Fiume): daily reports (copies)
Commission Interalliée d'Enquête de Fiume: Procès-verbaux et rapport
[Frank L. Polk?]: memorandum to Admiral Knapp re: conversation with Mr. Pachitch about drafting of Italians in the Spalato district
Frank L. Polk: draft cables to the Secretary of State
H. S. Knapp: letters to Polk enclosing copies of letters from Rear Admiral Andrews
Frank L. Polk: cables exchanged with the Secretary of State (copies, one edited)
[Yugoslavian Delegation]: memorandum re: "What Italy Can Receive with the Consent of the Jugoslavs,"
Douglas W. Johnson: draft letter for Admiral Knapp to be sent to Admiral Andrews re: Andrews's letter of Aug 16
Douglas W. Johnson: "Draft telegram to the President" (draft, copy for transmission)
[Georges Clemenceau]: memorandum of Tittoni's proposed terms of settlement
Henry White and Douglas W. Johnson: draft cable re: conversations with Tittoni and recommended U.S. response to Italian claims
Frank L. Polk: cable to the Secretary of State (draft, copy)
Frank L. Polk: cables exchanged with the President and the Secretary of State (drafts, copies)
Henry White and Tasker H. Bliss: letter to Polk re: agreement with the British and French representatives on the Supreme Council
H. S. Knapp: memorandum re: border relations between Italian and Serbian troops
Frank L. Polk: letter to Balfour re: the President's probable attitude toward the latest Italian proposal (carbon)
Georges Clemenceau and David Lloyd George: "Projet de cable au President Wilson" (carbon, copy in translation)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chronological Files has six sections: Telephone Logs, Cables to Ammission, Cables from Ammission, Interviews with the French Press, Supreme Council Resolutions, and Ammission Reports and Bulletins . Each is in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Politics and Memorabilia has four sections: General ; Programs, Invitations, Menus; Scrapbooks; and Card Index . The first three sections are in chronological order except that oversize items belonging to the General section are in a separate folio.

The Card Index was prepared before the collection was reprocessed. Its locations (drawer numbers) correspond to those of the old register, and are no longer meaningful. But it also affords a detailed subject index to the correspondence, and may serve to supplement the partial index that follows in this register.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a list of correspondents whose letters were removed from Charles Seymour's subject arrangement of the Polk Papers (the residue of which is now the basis of Series III, Subject Files) and arranged alphabetically in what is now Series I, Correspondence. The names are arranged alphabetically by subject (as chosen by Seymour, and slightly different from the subjects used in Series III). The subjects also are in alphabetical order.
Seymour did not arrange all correspondence by subject, and so this is only a partial subject index to Series I. Polk's most frequent correspondents are especially underrepresented.
